detail.content: Scally, Robert    | Department of History | New York University                                      NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE             Department of History     Arts & Science                      Back to Home           Robert Scally   Professor Emeritus of History, Irish Studies; Inaugural Director, Glucksman Ireland House     Princeton University, Ph.D. 1967   Office Address:   Glucksman Ireland House, #1 Washington Mews, NY, NY 10003   Email:        Phone:   212.998.3950   Fax:   212.995.4373   Areas of Research/Interest:   Modern European history; English social history; Irish history.     Affiliated with other departments or programs:   Inaugural Director, Glucksman Ireland House     Bio   Professor Robert Scally joined the New York University History Department in 1965 after receiving his Ph.D. from Princeton. His earliest research and teaching concentrated on British History and European Intellectual History, reflected in the publication of The Origins of the Lloyd George Coalition: The Politics of Social-Imperialism (Princeton UP, 1975) and his editorship of Forces of Order and Movement in Europe since 1815 .      In the 1980’s Professor Scally undertook research on Atlantic migrations of the nineteenth century, becoming an authority on Irish emigration in the era of the Great Famine. His critically acclaimed book, The End of Hidden Ireland: Famine, Rebellion and Emigration, 1832-1848 was published by Oxford University Press in 1995.      Instrumental in the early development the New York University Center for Irish Studies, Professor Scally was appointed the inaugural Director of Glucksman Ireland House in 1993, and oversaw the development of a highly successful undergraduate academic program and public event series, in addition to a lecture series and visiting professors program, which brought the cream of academic and literary minds to teach and speak at NYU. As Director, he organized the International Conference on Hunger at NYU in 1995 and chaired a historical advisory committee for the New York State Famine Curriculum, mandated by New York State for the public school system in 1997.      On a more personal level, Professor Scally recently commented that his time as Director of Ireland House, “presented me with a most unexpected and precious personal experience which reopened to me a deeper consciousness of where I had come from and where I belonged that I had nearly forgotten.”   Selected Works:   The End of Hidden Ireland: Rebellion, Eviction and Emigration, 1832-1848 (Oxford University Press, March, 1995) Paperback edition: 1996   "The Famine Emigration from Ireland, 1845-53," a chapter in The Cambridge Survey of World Migration (Cambridge, Cambridge U.P., 1996)    "External Factors in the Famine Migration," Proceedings of the Ulster-American Folk Park Museum Conference, Ulster Historical Foundation and Queens Univ. Belfast, 1997.    "Stony-Hearted Stepmother: Liverpool and the Irish," The Irish in America (1997), Hyperion Press.    "Crime, Punishment and Hunger: the System of Penal Transportation during the Famine," presented at Cambridge Univ., March, 1996, expected publication, Spring, 1998.    American Irish Desk Reference , supervising editor, Random House, Spring 2000.    "The Great Famine," Encyclopedia of the Irish in America (U. of Notre Dame Press, 1999.     Update your faculty profile         Updated on 03/08/2013             Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Scally, Robert    | Department of History | New York University                                      NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE             Department of History     Arts & Science                      Back to Home           Robert Scally   Professor Emeritus of History, Irish Studies; Inaugural Director, Glucksman Ireland House     Princeton University, Ph.D. 1967   Office Address:   Glucksman Ireland House, #1 Washington Mews, NY, NY 10003   Email:        Phone:   212.998.3950   Fax:   212.995.4373   Areas of Research/Interest:   Modern European history; English social history; Irish history.     Affiliated with other departments or programs:   Inaugural Director, Glucksman Ireland House     Bio   Professor Robert Scally joined the New York University History Department in 1965 after receiving his Ph.D. from Princeton. His earliest research and teaching concentrated on British History and European Intellectual History, reflected in the publication of The Origins of the Lloyd George Coalition: The Politics of Social-Imperialism (Princeton UP, 1975) and his editorship of Forces of Order and Movement in Europe since 1815 .      In the 1980’s Professor Scally undertook research on Atlantic migrations of the nineteenth century, becoming an authority on Irish emigration in the era of the Great Famine. His critically acclaimed book, The End of Hidden Ireland: Famine, Rebellion and Emigration, 1832-1848 was published by Oxford University Press in 1995.      Instrumental in the early development the New York University Center for Irish Studies, Professor Scally was appointed the inaugural Director of Glucksman Ireland House in 1993, and oversaw the development of a highly successful undergraduate academic program and public event series, in addition to a lecture series and visiting professors program, which brought the cream of academic and literary minds to teach and speak at NYU. As Director, he organized the International Conference on Hunger at NYU in 1995 and chaired a historical advisory committee for the New York State Famine Curriculum, mandated by New York State for the public school system in 1997.      On a more personal level, Professor Scally recently commented that his time as Director of Ireland House, “presented me with a most unexpected and precious personal experience which reopened to me a deeper consciousness of where I had come from and where I belonged that I had nearly forgotten.”   Selected Works:   The End of Hidden Ireland: Rebellion, Eviction and Emigration, 1832-1848 (Oxford University Press, March, 1995) Paperback edition: 1996   "The Famine Emigration from Ireland, 1845-53," a chapter in The Cambridge Survey of World Migration (Cambridge, Cambridge U.P., 1996)    "External Factors in the Famine Migration," Proceedings of the Ulster-American Folk Park Museum Conference, Ulster Historical Foundation and Queens Univ. Belfast, 1997.    "Stony-Hearted Stepmother: Liverpool and the Irish," The Irish in America (1997), Hyperion Press.    "Crime, Punishment and Hunger: the System of Penal Transportation during the Famine," presented at Cambridge Univ., March, 1996, expected publication, Spring, 1998.    American Irish Desk Reference , supervising editor, Random House, Spring 2000.    "The Great Famine," Encyclopedia of the Irish in America (U. of Notre Dame Press, 1999. Robert Scally's Teaching and Research Interests    | Department of History | New York University                                  NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE             Department of History     Arts & Science                      Back to Home       Robert Scally's Teaching and Research Interests   Research Interests:    Early years of research projects concentrated on British and European political and social history, resulting in The Origins of the Lloyd George Coalition: The Politics of Social-Imperialism, 1900-1918 (Princeton UP, 1975) and Forces of Order and Movement in Europe since 1815 (Houghton Mifflin, 1971) and various scholarly articles. These projects were later followed by research on Liverpool as a center of the Atlantic migrations of the 19 th century and through that to Irish emigration before and after the period of the famine of 1845-1853 ["Liverpool Ships and Irish Emigration in the Age of Sail," Journal of Social History17 /1 (1986) and The End of Hidden Ireland: Famine, Rebellion and Emigration, 1832-1848 (Oxford UP, 1995).    As Director of Glucksman Ireland House and the Program in Irish Studies, Prof. Scally was the principal organizer of the International Conference on Hunger at NYU in 1995 and various other scholarly meetings and public events on Irish history and culture from 1993 to the present. Prof. Scally recently acted as chair of the historical advisory committee for the New York State Famine Curriculum, mandated by New York State for the public school system in 1997.    Prof. Scally is currently engaged in research on the Irish diaspora worldwide, on an ethnological study of the pattern of settlement and subsequent history of the 1847-48 emigrants of Ballykilcline, the Irish townland at the core of The End of Hidden Ireland , and the writing of an historical novel based on that experience.     Teaching Interests:    Principal teaching offerings have been on European Social History since 1750, Modern British and Irish History, the three course sequence in Irish History since 1600 and, in Spring 2002, the Atlantic Migrations from 1600 to the Present. In each case the approach has been transnational and comparative, including recent joint teaching with Prof. Hasia Diner on Irish and Jewish Immigration to the U.S.             Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science
